article_author: ['Jessie Yeung', 'Julia Hollingsworth', 'Adam Renton', 'Joshua Berlinger', 'Sana Noor Haq', 'Blathnaid Healy', 'Adrienne Vogt', 'Meg Wagner', 'Melissa Macaya']
article_text:
US and NATO officials monitoring the war in Ukraine noticed a pronounced shift earlier this week in Russiaâ€™s strategyâ€”namely, that Russia now appears poised to â€œbombard cities into submission," which could inflict significant civilian casualties, a senior western intelligence official told CNN.

â€œThe heavier weapons are not just heavier in their in the weight, they're also heavier in terms of the damage that they can inflict,â€ the official said. â€œAnd they're far less discriminant. So, more casualties.â€

â€œIt is a very crude approach,â€ the official added. He said his experience with Russian leadership and Putin "leads me to judge that they have a completely different standard when it comes to respect for human life."

More background: US officials have warned in recent days that Russia's strategy appeared to be shifting from focusing primarily on military targets to targeting civilians, amid the realization that an initial plan to quickly capture Kyiv and topple the government had failed.

"The days to come are likely to be worse, with more death, more suffering, and more destruction, as the Russian armed forces bring in heavier weaponry and continue their attacks across the country," NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg said on Friday.

US Secretary of State Antony Blinken echoed the sentiment during a news conference in Brussels Friday where he is meeting with European allies.

â€œThe Kremlinâ€™s attacks are inflicting an ever-increasing toll on civilians there. Hundreds if not thousands of Ukrainians have been killed, many more wounded, as have citizens of other countries. More than a million refugees have fled Ukraine to neighboring countries. Millions of people across Ukraine are trapped in increasingly dire conditions as Russia destroys more critical infrastructure,â€ Blinken said.

The Washington Post first reported that significant civilian casualties, â€œmassive loss of human life,â€ are likely in the days ahead, according to a senior Western intelligence official.

Blinken and Stoltenberg on Friday also pushed back against calls for a no-fly zone to be set up in Ukraine, warning that it could lead to a "full-fledged war in Europe" and saying they're doing what they can to help Ukraine defend itself against Russia's invasion.

In separate news conferences in Brussels Friday, both argued that a NATO no-fly zone simply wasn't realistic because of the risk that it would lead to a direct conflict between Russia and NATO.

Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned NATO's decision to rule out the implementation of a no-fly zone over the country in a Facebook address late on Friday.

Zelensky said NATO's leadership on Friday: "Gave the green light for further bombing of Ukrainian towns and villages, refusing to make a no-fly zone. You could have closed the sky!"

CNN's Jeremy Herb contributed reporting to this post.

(CNN) Russia is poised to deploy up to 1,000 more mercenaries to Ukraine in the coming days and weeks, as a senior Western intelligence official warned Moscow could "bombard cities into submission," an escalation that could lead to significant civilian casualties.

The US has already seen "some indications" that Russian mercenaries may be involved in Moscow's invasion of Ukraine "in some places," a senior defense official said earlier this week, but it wasn't clear exactly where or in what numbers.

"We've seen some indications that they're being employed," the official said.

Now a US official tells CNN that Russia is planning to deploy up to 1,000 more mercenaries in the near future.

Some Russian forces have struggled with morale issues and setbacks on the battlefield, including a massive convoy north of Kyiv that has remained largely stalled for the past several days.

Read More

article_text:
Russia is poised to deploy up to 1,000 more mercenaries to Ukraine in the coming days and weeks, as a senior Western intelligence official warned Moscow could "bombard cities into submission," an escalation that could lead to significant civilian casualties.

The US has already seen "some indications" that Russian mercenaries may be involved in Moscow's invasion of Ukraine "in some places," a senior defense official said earlier this week, but it wasn't clear exactly where or in what numbers.

"We've seen some indications that they're being employed," the official said.

Now, a US official tells CNN that Russia is planning to deploy up to 1,000 more mercenaries in the near future.

Stalled forces: Some Russian forces have struggled with morale issues and setbacks on the battlefield, including a massive convoy north of Kyiv that has remained largely stalled for the past several days.

The mercenary forces would fortify the flagging units, the official said, as Russia's invasion of Ukraine enters its second weekend.

The official added that the US believes the mercenaries already in Ukraine have "performed poorly when facing the stiffer-than-expected resistance from the Ukrainians," and that as many as 200 such mercenaries have already been killed in the war as of late February.

Meanwhile, US and Western officials expect Russia to increase the pace and strength of its strikes on key Ukrainian population centers, including the capital Kyiv.

An intensifying assault: Russia now seems prepared to â€œbombard cities into submission,â€ one senior western intelligence official said on Friday, which could include a significant increase in the number of civilian casualties.

â€œItâ€™s a very crude approach,â€ the official said. â€œThe heavier weapons are not just heavier in the weight, theyâ€™re also heavier in terms of the damage that they can inflict. And theyâ€™re far less discriminant.â€

Other officials have noticed a shift in Russian strategy from military targets to civilians, with more attacks becoming focused on population centers.

"The days to come are likely to be worse, with more death, more suffering, and more destruction, as the Russian armed forces bring in heavier weaponry and continue their attacks across the country," NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg said on Friday.

US Secretary of State Antony Blinken echoed the sentiment during a press conference in Brussels Friday where he is meeting with European allies.

article_author: ['Jessie Yeung', 'Steve George', 'Laura Smith-Spark', 'Angela Dewan', 'Adrienne Vogt', 'Joe Ruiz', 'Alaa Elassar']
article_text:
As the war in Ukraine drags into its second week, a Western intelligence official has warned Russia could be looking to "bombard cities into submission," potentially leading to high numbers of civilian casualties. Here's the latest:

Alarm at nuclear plant: The United Nations Security Council held an emergency meeting on Friday, where a top UN official called for cooperation with the UNâ€™s nuclear watchdog and for safe passage in Ukraine.

This comes after a fire broke out at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant in Ukraine, caused by Russian shelling sparking fears of a potential nuclear incident. Firefighters were able to put out the blaze, despite being initially blocked by Russian troops. And radiation levels appear normal, Ukrainian and US officials say. Operations are now continuing at the plant, but it was "occupied" by Russian forces early Friday, said Ukrainian authorities.

Tensions at the UN: At the emergency meeting, the Russian ambassador to the UN claimed there were â€œlies about how Russian troops attacked the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant.â€

The Ukrainian ambassador pushed back, calling his Russian counterpart "a liar," and said the plant sustained damage.

The US ambassador to the UN said the world had â€œnarrowly avertedâ€ nuclear catastrophe on Friday, but warned that Russian troops are approaching Ukraineâ€™s second-largest nuclear facility.

Airspace dispute: Despite Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky's pleas for NATO to establish a no-fly zone over Ukraine, US Secretary of State Blinken and NATO's chief Stoltenberg turned down the request.

They warned that the only way to implement a no-fly zone would be to "send NATO planes into Ukrainian airspace and to shoot down Russian planes, and that could lead to a full-fledged war in Europe."

Zelensky condemned NATO's decision, saying it gave Russia the â€œgreen lightâ€ for further attacks of Ukrainian towns.

Military attacks on civilian areas: Videos show the extent of destruction in key Ukrainian cities after Russian military strikes. An apartment complex was hit in the northern city of Chernihiv, with walls blown apart and rubble everywhere.

Russian troops continue laying siege to Mariupol, a strategically important city on the southern coast, and Kharkiv, the country's second-largest city in the northeast. A standoff is ongoing in the southern city of Mykolaiv.

Rising toll: The war has killed at least 331 civilians, the UN estimates, though the real toll could be far higher. More than 1.2 million refugees have fled Ukraine since the invasion began on February 24, with more than half entering Poland.

article_text:
As the war in Ukraine drags into its second week, a Western intelligence official has warned Russia could be looking to "bombard cities into submission," potentially leading to high numbers of civilian casualties. Here's the latest:

This comes after a fire broke out at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant in Ukraine, caused by Russian shelling sparking fears of a potential nuclear incident. Operations are now continuing at the plant, but it was "occupied" by Russian forces early Friday, said Ukrainian authorities.

The Ukrainian ambassador pushed back, calling his Russian counterpart "a liar," and said the plant sustained damage.

The US ambassador to the UN said the world had â€œnarrowly avertedâ€ nuclear catastrophe on Friday, but warned that Russian troops are approaching Ukraineâ€™s second-largest nuclear facility.

They warned that the only way to implement a no-fly zone would be to "send NATO planes into Ukrainian airspace and to shoot down Russian planes, and that could lead to a full-fledged war in Europe."

Zelensky condemned NATO's decision, saying it gave Russia the â€œgreen lightâ€ for further attacks of Ukrainian towns.

Russian troops continue laying siege to Mariupol, a strategically important city on the southern coast, and Kharkiv, the country's second-largest city in the northeast. A standoff is ongoing in the southern city of Mykolaiv.

NEW DELHI: US and NATO officials monitoring the war in Ukraine noticed a pronounced shift earlier this week in Russias strategy, namely that Moscow now appears poised to "bombard cities into submission" which could inflict significant civilian casualties, CNN reported.

"The heavier weapons are not just heavier in their weight, they're also heavier in terms of the damage that they can inflict", one of the officials said. "And they're far less discriminant. So, more casualties."

"It is a very crude approach, " the official added.

US officials have warned in recent days that Russia's strategy appeared to be shifting from focusing primarily on military targets to targeting civilians, amid the realisation that an initial plan to quickly capture Kyiv and topple the government had failed, CNN reported.

"The days to come are likely to be worse, with more death, more suffering, and more destruction, as the Russian armed forces bring in heavier weaponry and continue their attacks across the country, " NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg said on Friday.

The Washington Post first reported that significant civilian casualties, "massive loss of human life", are likely in the days ahead, according to a senior Western intelligence official.

Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned NATO's decision to rule out the implementation of a no-fly zone over the country in a Facebook address late on Friday, CNN reported.

Zelensky said NATO's leadership "gave the green light for further bombing of Ukrainian towns and villages, refusing to make a no-fly zone. You could have closed the sky".

By Natasha Bertrand, Oren Liebermann and Barbara Starr, CNN

Russia is poised to deploy up to 1,000 more mercenaries to Ukraine in the coming days and weeks, as a senior Western intelligence official warned Moscow could â€œbombard cities into submission,â€ an escalation that could lead to significant civilian casualties.

The US has already seen â€œsome indicationsâ€ that Russian mercenaries may be involved in Moscowâ€™s invasion of Ukraine â€œin some places,â€ a senior defense official said earlier this week, but it wasnâ€™t clear exactly where or in what numbers.

â€œWeâ€™ve seen some indications that theyâ€™re being employed,â€ the official said.

Now a US official tells CNN that Russia is planning to deploy up to 1,000 more mercenaries in the near future.

Some Russian forces have struggled with morale issues and setbacks on the battlefield, including a massive convoy north of Kyiv that has remained largely stalled for the past several days.

The mercenary forces would fortify the flagging units, the official said, as Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine enters its second weekend.

The official added that the US believes the mercenaries already in Ukraine have â€œperformed poorly when facing the stiffer-than-expected resistance from the Ukrainians,â€ and that as many as 200 such mercenaries have already been killed in the war as of late February.

Meanwhile, US and western officials expect Russia to increase the pace and strength of its strikes on key Ukrainian population centers, including the capital of Kyiv, from which Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has broadcast steady but defiant messages against Russiaâ€™s aggression.

Russia now seems prepared to â€œbombard cities into submission,â€ one senior western intelligence official said on Friday, which could include a significant increase in the number of civilian casualties.

â€œItâ€™s a very crude approach,â€ the official said. â€œThe heavier weapons are not just heavier in the weight, theyâ€™re also heavier in terms of the damage that they can inflict. And theyâ€™re far less discriminant.â€

Other officials have noticed a shift in Russian strategy from military targets to civilians, with more attacks becoming focused on population centers. The new approach comes after Russian President Vladimir Putin failed to get the quick victory he wanted, and the Russian military has faced a stiff and determined Ukrainian resistance across the country.

In the face of the resistance, the attacks will increase, officials warned.

â€œThe days to come are likely to be worse, with more death, more suffering, and more destruction, as the Russian armed forces bring in heavier weaponry and continue their attacks across the country,â€ NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg said on Friday.

US Secretary of State Antony Blinken echoed the sentiment during a news conference in Brussels Friday where he is meeting with European allies.

â€œThe Kremlinâ€™s attacks are inflicting an ever-increasing toll on civilians there,â€ Blinken said. â€œHundreds if not thousands of Ukrainians have been killed, many more wounded, as have citizens of other countries. More than a million refugees have fled Ukraine to neighboring countries. Millions of people across Ukraine are trapped in increasingly dire conditions as Russia destroys more critical infrastructure.â€

The-CNN-Wire

Increasing its offensive against Ukraine, Russia is set to deploy up to 1,000 more mercenaries in the war-ravaged country in the coming days and weeks, a senior Western intelligence official told CNN. He warned that Moscow could "bombard Ukrainian cities into submission" - an escalation that would cause significant civilian casualties.

The US has already seen "some indications" that Russian mercenaries may be involved in Moscow's invasion of Ukraine "in some places," a senior defence official said earlier this week, without stating the exact figures. Now, a US official has stated that Russia is planning to deploy up to 1,000 more mercenaries in the near future.

The mercenary forces would fortify the flagging units, as Russia's invasion of Ukraine entered its second weekend. The US believes Russian mercenaries already in Ukraine have "performed poorly when facing resistance from the Ukrainians," and that 200 of them have already been killed in the war as of late February.

"Russia to bombard Ukraine cities into submission"

Meanwhile, US and western officials expect Russia to increase the pace and strength of its strikes on key Ukrainian population centres, including Kyiv, from which Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has broadcast strong messages against Russian aggression.

"Russia now seems prepared to bombard cities into submission. It's a very crude approach," the official said. "The heavier weapons are not just heavier in the weight, they're also heavier in terms of the damage that they can inflict. And they're far less discriminant."

Top US and NATO officials on Friday turned down calls for a no-fly zone to be set up in Ukraine, warning that it could lead to a "full-fledged war in Europe" and saying that they are doing what they can to help Ukraine defend itself against Russia's invasion. NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg said at a presser, that banning the foreign planes over Ukraineâ€™s airspace would imply NATO air support shooting down Russian missiles and warplanes, an act that can further flare the conflict." He however warned that days to come are likely to be worse, with more death, more suffering, and more destruction, as the Russian armed forces bring in heavier weaponry and continue their attacks across the country.

Image: AP

article_author: ['Mersiha Gadzo Farah Najjar Usaid Siddiqui', 'Mersiha Gadzo', 'Farah Najjar', 'Usaid Siddiqui']
article_text:
Ukraine-Russia news from March 5: Ceasefire fails in the key city, with allegations of violations by both Russia and Ukraine.

Russia resumes its offensive on the strategic port city of Mariupol, after a temporary ceasefire failed with allegations of violations by both sides.

Russiaâ€™s flagship airline Aeroflot says it will suspend all its international flights from March 8 except Belarus, amid Western sanctions on Moscow over its invasion of Ukraine.

Multiple news outlets say they will pause their work inside Russia, citing a new law that could mean jail for those found to be intentionally spreading â€œfakeâ€ news.

More than 1.2 million people have fled Ukraine to neighbouring countries, according to the United Nations.

This live blog is now closed; thank you for joining us. For the latest news on March 6, go here.

Here were the updates for March 5:

5 Mar 2022 - 20:52 GMT

Hundreds of students trapped in Ukraineâ€™s Sumy amid shelling

At least 1,500 foreign students are trapped in the northeastern Ukrainian city of Sumy, as shelling from the Russian army continues for a tenth day after humanitarian corridors failed to materialise.

Shivangi Shibu, a 25-year-old medical student from India, was woken up in her university hostel at dawn on Saturday by the sound of shelling.

Read more here.

5 Mar 2022 - 20:42 GMT

Almost 11,500 Turkish citizens evacuated: Minister

Turkey has evacuated 11,496 citizens from Ukraine since Russia launched a war on its neighbour, the Turkish foreign minister said.

A further 273 Turkish people left Ukraine on Saturday, Mevlut Cavusoglu said on Twitter.

5 Mar 2022 - 20:13 GMT

Protests in solidarity with Ukraine in New York

Hundreds of people rallied in New York Cityâ€™s Times Square to show solidarity with Ukraine.

Many attendees were waving Ukrainian flags or draped the flag around their shoulders at the afternoon demonstration.

Others brought signs decrying Russian leader Putin or calling for a no-fly zone to be imposed over Ukraine.

5 Mar 2022 - 19:55 GMT

UN committed to scaled-up humanitarian efforts

Secretary-General Antonio Guterres says the United Nations is committed to scaling up its humanitarian operations to help both those who have stayed in Ukraine and the millions who have fled.

Guterres relayed the promise to Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba in a phone call on Saturday, UN spokesman Stephane Dujarric said.

Dujarric said the two also discussed the conditions for safely evacuating civilians, including foreigners, from combat zones.

5 Mar 2022 - 19:20 GMT

Sanctions on Russia should not affect Iran deal: US

New US sanctions imposed on Russia are not related to the 2015 Iran nuclear deal and should not have any impact on a potential revival of that agreement, a US State Department spokesperson said.

â€œThe new Russia-related sanctions are unrelated to the JCPOA and should not have any impact on its potential implementation,â€ the spokesperson said, referring to the 2015 deal by its formal name, the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action.

â€œWe continue to engage with Russia on a return to full implementation of the JCPOA. Russia shares a common interest in ensuring Iran never acquires a nuclear weapon. â€

5 Mar 2022 - 19:07 GMT

Ceasefire call by Russia a â€˜fictionâ€™: Writer

A UK-based author says Russiaâ€™s announcement of the ceasefire in Mariupol was a â€œfictionâ€, adding Moscow was following a â€œscriptâ€ similar to its actions in Syria.

â€œRussia has repeated a very familiar script to set these [ceasefires] up and entice people into leaving the city into evacuating through what was supposed to be a safe corridor, and then tried to shell them in order to bottleneck as many people as possible into an area that was going to come under attack,â€ Keir Giles of the Conflict Studies Research Centre in London told Al Jazeera from Northamptonshire.

â€œFortunately, it appears that Ukrainian authorities â€“ who already letâ€™s not forget have been at war with Russia for eight years, and probably knew what was coming, held back from actually launching all of their civilian evacuees down this humanitarian corridor,â€ he added.

5 Mar 2022 - 18:59 GMT

Russian forces advancing towards third nuclear facility: Zelenskyy

Ukraineâ€™s president says Russian forces have now seized two Ukrainian nuclear power plants and are advancing toward a third, he told US senators during a call.

Zelenskyy says the third plant currently under threat is the Yuzhnoukrainsk nuclear power plant, located 120km (75 miles) north of Mykolaiv.

5 Mar 2022 - 18:51 GMT

Zelenskyy makes â€˜desperate pleaâ€™ to US senators

Ukrainian President Zelenskyy made a â€œdesperate pleaâ€ to US senators to help his country get more planes to help the country fight the Russian invasion.

Zelenskyy made the request on a call joined by more than 300 people, including senators, some House legislators and aides.

Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, a Democrat from New York, said in a statement that Zelenskyy made a â€œdesperate plea for Eastern European countries to provide Russian-made planes to Ukraineâ€.

5 Mar 2022 - 18:45 GMT

UK accuse Russia of Mariupol ceasefire plan to reset forces

The United Kingdom said on Saturday that Russiaâ€™s proposed ceasefire in the Ukrainian city of Mariupol was probably an attempt to deflect international condemnation while giving itself a chance to reset its forces for a renewed offensive.

â€œBy accusing Ukraine of breaking the agreement, Russia is likely seeking to shift responsibility for current and future civilian casualties in the city,â€ the UK defence ministry said in an intelligence update.

5 Mar 2022 - 18:24 GMT

Israel PM heads to Berlin to meet Scholz after Putin talks

Israelâ€™s prime minister was headed to Berlin for talks with the German chancellor following a three-hour meeting on the Ukraine conflict with Russian President Putin, his spokesperson said.

â€œPrime Minister Naftali Bennett is currently on his way from Moscow to Berlin, where he will meet with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz,â€ Bennettâ€™s spokesperson said in a statement.

5 Mar 2022 - 18:06 GMT

Russia resumes â€˜offensiveâ€™ after Mariupol ceasefire: Ministry

Russiaâ€™s defence ministry says it has resumed â€œoffensive actionsâ€ in Ukraine after announcing a ceasefire earlier in the day to allow residents of two besieged cities to evacuate.

â€œDue to the unwillingness of the Ukrainian side to influence nationalists or extend the ceasefire, offensive actions have been resumed at 18:00 Moscow time [15:00 GMT],â€ Defence Ministry Spokesperson Igor Konashenkov said in a video briefing.

Earlier, city officials in Mariupol said in a statement on social media that since the Russian side did not adhere to the ceasefire, â€œthe evacuation of the civilian population has been postponedâ€.

5 Mar 2022 - 17:58 GMT

Thousands rally in Paris in solidarity with Ukraine

Several thousand protesters took to the streets of Paris to show their support for Ukraine.

Protesters lined the streets of the French capital holding up banners and waving Ukrainian flags as they called on Russia to withdraw its troops from Ukrainian territory.

Among them was Ukraineâ€™s ambassador to France, Vadym Omelchenko.

â€œRight now every minute in Ukraine, Russian armed forces are killing civilians and children,â€ Omelchenko said as he marched alongside other protesters.

5 Mar 2022 - 17:33 GMT

Talks to resume on Monday: Ukraine negotiator

Russia and Ukraine on Monday will hold a third round of talks to try end the crisis, Ukrainian Negotiator David Arakhamiya said in a Facebook post, without providing further details.

On Thursday, the sides agreed to open humanitarian corridors to allow civilians out of some combat zones, although there have been delays in implementing them.

5 Mar 2022 - 17:12 GMT

Protest in London against Ukraine war

Hundreds have gathered in central London to protest Russiaâ€™s attack on Ukraine.

Carrying placards reading â€™â€™Protect Europe: Save Ukraineâ€³ and waving the countryâ€™s blue and yellow flag, demonstrators chanted, â€œStop Putin, stop the war.â€

The rally in Londonâ€™s Trafalgar Square began with a prayer from Archbishop Claudio Gugerotti, the papal nuncio to Great Britain.

5 Mar 2022 - 16:58 GMT

Aeroflot to halt international flights

Russiaâ€™s flagship carrier Aeroflot, has announced that it will halt all international flights except to Belarus starting March 8.

The move by Russiaâ€™s biggest state-owned airline comes after the countryâ€™s aviation agency, Rosaviatsiya, recommended that all Russian airlines with foreign-leased planes halt both passenger and cargo flights abroad.

It cited a high risk of foreign-leased planes being impounded as part of Western sanctions that ban leasing of planes to Russia.

Read more here.

5 Mar 2022 - 16:36 GMT

Israelâ€™s Bennett meets Putin in Moscow

Israeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett met with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Moscow on Saturday to discuss the Ukraine crisis, his spokesperson said.

Israel has offered to mediate in the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, though officials have previously played down expectations of a breakthrough.

5 Mar 2022 - 16:24 GMT

Analyst: Russia yet to bring full military force to Ukraine

Military Analyst Mason Clark, of the Institute for the Study of War, explains why Russia has not used its full military force against Ukraine.â€Itâ€™s frankly miraculous that they have allowed the Ukrainian Air Force to remain operational â€¦ when they should have theoretically had the capabilities to ground it very early on in operations,â€ he told Al Jazeera.

â€œSo a lot of those higher-end Russian capabilities that we would expect, we havenâ€™t actually seen used yet. It doesnâ€™t, of course, mean that they wonâ€™t ever be used, and we are beginning to see some indications of Russians using greater tactical airpower,â€ he said.

â€œAnd of course, as is rightly getting a lot of attention, using possible thermobaric munitions and rocket artillery against civilian targets in Kharkiv and elsewhere.â€

Watch the video below for more.

5 Mar 2022 - 16:04 GMT

Websites in Ukraine under â€˜nonstopâ€™ attack: Cyber watchdog

Ukrainian websites have been under nonstop attack from Russian hackers since the Kremlin launched an invasion of the country last month, Kyivâ€™s cyber watchdog agency revealed.

Ukraineâ€™s State Service of Special Communications and Information Protection said that â€œRussian hackers keep on attacking Ukrainian information resources nonstopâ€.

Russian hackers keep on attacking Ukrainian information resources nonstop

Since the beginning of invasion, DDos attacks have been primarily aimed at the resources of Verkhovna Rada, Cabinet of Ministers, President of Ukraine, Defense Ministry and Internal Affairs Ministry â€” SSSCIP Ukraine (@dsszzi) March 5, 2022

5 Mar 2022 - 15:41 GMT

Russians in Germany receiving threats: Embassy

The Russian embassy in Berlin has revealed it got hundreds of complaints in the past three days from Russians in Germany saying they had received threatening messages.

â€œWe hold all manifestations of discrimination and infringement of the

rights of our citizens and the Russian-speaking population in Germany

to be unacceptable,â€ the embassy said.

5 Mar 2022 - 15:31 GMT

â€˜Putin wonâ€™t stopâ€™: Ex-Russian deputy foreign minister

Andrei Fedorov, a former deputy foreign minister of Russia, told Al Jazeera Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s objective is to surround Ukraineâ€™s capital, Kyiv, and then give President Volodomyr Zelenskyy an ultimatum.

â€œHe declared a very clear goal that Ukraine, as it is today, should be changed,â€ Fedorov said from Moscow. â€œIâ€™ve known him for many years, he will not stop. Most probably, in the next 5-6 days, the military operation will be extended to much more territory, including Odesa,â€ he predicted.

â€œThe Russian army will surround Kyiv, and then there will be a kind of ultimatum for maybe 24 hours for Zelenskyy to resign, for the government to resign, to declare something like an interim government or something like this, because from military point of view, itâ€™s very dangerous to start a military attack on Kyiv â€“ it can bring a lot of damages,â€ Fedorov added.

â€œAlso, letâ€™s not forget that Kiev is playing a very important role in Russiaâ€™s history; in Russia itâ€™s called the mother of all Russian cities.â€

5 Mar 2022 - 15:07 GMT

No reason for martial law in Russia: Putin

The Russian leader says there is nothing that warrants imposing martial law in Russia at this point.

Putinâ€™s comment followed days of speculation that the introduction of martial law could be imminent.

The Russian president said that â€œmartial law is imposed in a country â€¦ in the event of external aggression, including in specific areas of hostilities. But we donâ€™t have such a situation, and I hope we wonâ€™tâ€.

5 Mar 2022 - 14:55 GMT

UN: More than 350 civilians confirmed killed in Ukraine

At least 351 civilians are confirmed to have been killed in Ukraine, a UN monitoring mission said.

Many of the civilian casualties were due to explosive weapons with a wide impact area, including shelling from heavy artillery and multi-launch rocket systems, and from missile and air raids, monitors from the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR) revealed.

â€œOHCHR believes that the real figures are considerably higher, especially in Government-controlled territory and especially in recent days, as the receipt of information from some locations where intensive hostilities have been going on was delayed and many reports were still pending corroboration,â€ it said.

5 Mar 2022 - 14:38 GMT

Germany to build LNG terminal

Germany has said it would build a liquefied natural gas terminal on its North Sea coast, to reduce its dependency on Russian gas imports.

â€œIt is necessary to reduce our dependence on Russian gas as quickly as possibleâ€ in light of Moscowâ€™s aggression, Economy and Climate Minister Robert Habeck said in a statement.

Germany getting serious abt energy independence @KfW @RWE_AG & @Gasunie just signed a Memorandum of Understanding to build an LNG Terminal in BrunsbÃ¼ttel ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡ª It will be built with perspective to import green hydrogen @BMWK Robert Habeck welcomed the project https://t.co/btiI8Yop7m â€” JÃ¶rg Kukies (@joergkukies) March 5, 2022

5 Mar 2022 - 14:30 GMT

Italyâ€™s public TV RAI says suspends reporting

Italyâ€™s public television channel RAI has announced an immediate suspension of its operations from Russia after Moscow passed a bill allowing jail terms on media outlets publishing â€œfalse informationâ€ about the military.

â€œFollowing the approval of the law which gives heavy sentences for publishing information considered false by the authorities, RAI is suspending from today the journalistic services of its own reporters and correspondents in the Russian Federation,â€ the channel said in a statement.

5 Mar 2022 - 14:17 GMT

Putin: Nations thinking to impose no-fly zone party to conflict

The Russian president has warned that any nation contemplating imposing a no-fly zone over Ukraine would be considered by Moscow to be participating in â€œarmed conflictâ€.

â€œAny movement in this direction will be considered by us as participation in an armed conflict by that country,â€ Putin said during a meeting with Aeroflot employees.

He said a no-fly zone would have â€œcolossal and catastrophic consequences not only for Europe but also the whole worldâ€.

Read more here.

5 Mar 2022 - 14:06 GMT

Blinken speaks with Chinese FM: State Dept

â€˜Great sense of panicâ€™

5 Mar 2022 - 09:13 GMT

The US embassy in Ukraine has said that attacking a nuclear power plant is a war crime after Russia seized a Ukrainian nuclear facility that is the biggest in Europe.

â€œKnowing that new strikes and casualties are inevitable, NATO deliberately decided not to close the sky over Ukraine,â€ he said in a video published by the presidency.

4 Mar 2022 - 21:10 GMT

4 Mar 2022 - 21:02 GMT

4 Mar 2022 - 20:46 GMT

We support the initiative of IAEA Director General Grossi announced today for an agreement between Ukraine and Russia to ensure the safety and security of nuclear facilities in Ukraine.â€

US and NATO officials monitoring the war in Ukraine noticed a pronounced shift earlier this week in Russiaâ€™s strategyâ€”namely, that Russia now appears poised to â€œbombard cities into submission,â€ which could inflict significant civilian casualties, a senior western intelligence official told CNN.

â€œIt is a very crude approach,â€ the official added. He said his experience with Russian leadership and Putin â€œleads me to judge that they have a completely different standard when it comes to respect for human life.â€

More background: US officials have warned in recent days that Russiaâ€™s strategy appeared to be shifting from focusing primarily on military targets to targeting civilians, amid the realization that an initial plan to quickly capture Kyiv and topple the government had failed.

â€œThe days to come are likely to be worse, with more death, more suffering, and more destruction, as the Russian armed forces bring in heavier weaponry and continue their attacks across the country,â€ NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg said on Friday.

US Secretary of State Antony Blinken echoed the sentiment during a news conference in Brussels Friday where he is meeting with European allies.

More than a million refugees have fled Ukraine to neighboring countries. Millions of people across Ukraine are trapped in increasingly dire conditions as Russia destroys more critical infrastructure,â€ Blinken said.

The Washington Post first reported that significant civilian casualties, â€œmassive loss of human life,â€ are likely in the days ahead, according to a senior Western intelligence official.

Blinken and Stoltenberg on Friday also pushed back against calls for a no-fly zone to be set up in Ukraine, warning that it could lead to a â€œfull-fledged war in Europeâ€ and saying theyâ€™re doing what they can to help Ukraine defend itself against Russiaâ€™s invasion.

In separate news conferences in Brussels Friday, both argued that a NATO no-fly zone simply wasnâ€™t realistic because of the risk that it would lead to a direct conflict between Russia and NATO.

Ukraineâ€™s President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned NATOâ€™s decision to rule out the implementation of a no-fly zone over the country in a Facebook address late on Friday.

Zelensky said NATOâ€™s leadership on Friday: â€œGave the green light for further bombing of Ukrainian towns and villages, refusing to make a no-fly zone. You could have closed the sky!â€
